body: The application automatically subscribes to all available currency pairs
We unsubscribe when the app closes, user can't close a tile
We get this out of the box with SignalR: we use SignalR groups which are cleaned automatically when a user is disconnected
done
Done
done
done
done
done.
done (in CurrencyPair the price stream is published/refcount)
done
done

data format -> done
Columns order and title -> done
closing, we have more detailed stories with the remaining stuff

The server UI now allows to add/remove currency pairs at runtime and this gets propagated to the client (add/remove tiles)

Also the reference data stuff is resilient to server restart.

Stale / Notional Box styling / Up+down arrows / Executing - done

Subscribing - not done
closing this and creating a new one for subscribing

The price repository now expects an update every 2 seconds. If no price is received during 2sec, a stale update is pushed in the stream.

It's also now possible to stale a price with the server UI.

- GBPUSD: Server waits 1.5sec to execute then sends a trade done.
- GBPJPY: Always rejects execution.
- EURJPY: Waits 5sec before sending trade response (times-out)
- EURCHF: Always slow to send a first price update.
done
Rejected style (should be red) and strikethrough -> done
Added animation on trade instered

Have a look at the implementation, what I measure is the time it takes between creating a price domain object and after populating the view model. The status bar display the max for all prices over the last second.

I've noticed the delay you are talking about and as I said in a previous email this delay is not on the dispatcher thread. Since WPF uses a background rendering thread I suspect that this thread is not able to keep up and a queue is building up there, but I don't know how to measure that.

I hear everybody saying don't do anything on the UI thread, this measure show that this is not true, at least for this use case (the UI thread processes 2k updates per second without adding latency on my laptop, not many apps are that demanding). 

Olivier

> On 10 Mar 2014, at 15:19, Lee Campbell notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> We currently show what appears to be latency to display the price, but must not taking into account all of the latency. On my i3 I can ramp up price-contribution to max, and then ramp down again to min, and the prices will keep ticking very quickly for many seconds after I ramp down. The problem here is the latency in the Footer status bar show ~40ms of latency which is clearly not true.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

I think you're seeing WPF behave exceptionally well because its dealing
with very few visual elements in the visual tree.. Not sure its a reason to
do everything on the UI thread.

I think a timestamp needs to be put on the dto from the server. Then at
each point in the chain latency can be measured
- off the wire
- translated into domain
- scheduled to UI
- rendered in the UI

As the demo runs both client and server off the same clock this could show
some other source of latency (i.e a queue somewhere)

I now display 2 latencies in the status bar:
- server to client latency: this is the time elapsed between the server creating the price tick and the client receiving it
- UI Latency: this is the time elapsed between the client receiving the price and after it has been displayed on the UI (ie. applied to the view model to be correct).

![image](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/1256913/2391170/783e5ff2-a963-11e3-8627-2da8bb649abf.png)

I do not see any queuing on my PC even at 5k updates / sec (when using ObserveLatestOn), Lee can you check if you still observe the queuing, and if yes are one of those latencies high?
Did a few one today (I updated the list in Paul's initial post)
done
